BLIST.ITEM:
ratproxyhttps://code.google.com/archive/p/ratproxy/
enHTML: a passive audit tool to detect server security issues

skipfishhttps://code.google.com/archive/p/skipfish/
enHTML: an active audit tool to detect server security issues

DOM Snitchhttps://code.google.com/archive/p/domsnitch/
enHTML: heuritics to find security issues in client-side code

burpBurphttps://portswigger.net/
enHTMLhttps://portswigger.net/blog/rssAtom: a Web proxy allowing snooping, replay…(personal notes../notes/burp.html
enHTML)

X.T: ZAP
PayloadsAllTheThings
Have I been pwned?
PortSwigger’s Web Security Academy
Sécurisation des sites Web et des e-mails
Personal notes
How can I get setuid shell scripts to work?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Since I'm fed up to explain my workmates that setuid scripts are a very bad idea, I now just send them this FAQ.

X.T: IP-spoofing Demystified
X.ST: (Trust-Relationship Exploitation)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is a short summary of the TCP/IP protocol, how to perform IP spoofing and how to avoid it.

X.T: Perl CGI problems

ARTICLE.COMMENT: rfp explains how to break a web server because of insecure CGI Perl scripts: embedded nul, unescaped backslash and pipes commands.

X.T: A practical vulnerability analysis

ARTICLE.COMMENT: PC Week proposed a challenge: break into their Linux server. This is a description of the winner method.

X.T: NT Web Technology Vulnerabilities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: In this article, rfp explains some holes in IIS, Cold Fusion and MS SQL server (FYI, there are some problems with the HTML page, it is better to read the source).

X.T: Examining Remote OS Detection using LPD Querying

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to recognise an OS by sending malformed request to the lpd daemon.

X.T: Detecting Loadable Kernel Modules (LKM)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This paper explains how to detect LKM rootkits.

X.T: Remote Vulnerabilities in Bugzilla

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A typical example of applying the methods described in the previous rain.forest.puppy’s article.

X.T: The Dangers of Allowing Users to Post Images

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some CGI scripts allowing user to post images to not check the input, this can be used to execute some GET methods.

X.T: Search Engines as a Security Threat

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Search engines can help to find vulnerable servers or can be used as anonymous proxies.

X.T: RPC without borders (surfing USA ...)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: SOAP::Lite is highly insecure: any loaded routine can be remotely called.

X.T: Linux kernel file offset pointer handling

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using a race condition on the file offset management to be able to read kernel memory.

X.T: Cache missing for fun and profit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to measure the memory access times to analyse cache hits/misses and break a cryptographic key.

X.T: How To Break Web Software - A look at security vulnerabilities in web software

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After some general stuff about the Web, Mike describes how the security attacks are evolving and gives some examples of current common security holes: session hijacking, cross-site scripting, HTTP response splitting… He also proposes the STRIDE (Spoofing, Tampering, Repudiation, Information disclosure, Denial of service, Escalation of privilege) framework to test Web applications.

X.T: How Cybercriminals Steal Money

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After some stats on cybercriminals deeds, NeilDaswani describes SQL injection, cross-site request forgery (XSRF), and cross-site script inclusion (XSSI) and how to avoid them.

X.T: Bash specially-crafted environment variables code injection attack

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A bad Bash bug: it is possible to inject a command by putting it at the end of a function in an environment variable.

X.T: Detecting and exploiting path-relative stylesheet import (PRSSI) vulnerabilities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Exploiting the fact that some frameworks handle a relative path to CSS files.

X.T: Krack Attacks (WiFi WPA2 Vulnerability) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple explanation of the Key Reinstallation Attack.

X.T: How a Dorm Room Minecraft Scam Brought Down the Internet
X.ST: A DDoS attack that crippled the internet wasn't the work of a nation-state. It was three college kids working an online gaming hustle.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A non-technical, but detailed, story of the Mirai botnet.

X.T: Unearthing Z͌̈́̾a͊̈́l͊̿g̏̉͆o̾̚̚S̝̬ͅc̬r̯̼͇ͅi̼͖̜̭͔p̲̘̘̹͖t̠͖̟̹͓͇ͅ with visual fuzzing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Playing with combining marks, but there is no security gap to exploit here.

X.T: Data Exfiltration via Formula Injection #Part1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using HTTP requests to get data from a spreadsheet or from the local filesystem.

X.T: Hackability inspector

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A tool to analyse the JavaScript objects of a browser.

X.T: Evading CSP with DOM-based dangling markup

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Exposing Intranets with reliable Browser-based Port scanning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to scan ports with Chrome, Firefox and Edge.

X.T: XS-Searching Google’s bug tracker to find out vulnerable source code
X.ST: Or how side-channel timing attacks aren’t that impractical

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using timing to extract information from monorail.

X.T: Secure Copy Vulnerability (SCP) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The description of a very old security hole found in scp.

X.T: XSS without parentheses and semi-colons

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all: injecting JavaScript expressions containing no parentheses nor semi-colons.

X.T: Provoking browser quirks with behavioural fuzzing

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using fuzz testing to detect improper handling of some characters in the HTML parser and in the JavaScript parser.

X.T: Bypassing CSP with policy injection

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Exploiting the fact that PayPal inserts a GET parameter in their CSP directive to override this one.

X.T: HTTP Desync Attacks: Request Smuggling Reborn

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to exploit the fact that servers of different layers handle invalid HTTP requests differently.

X.T: A look at the Windows 10 exploit Google Zero disclosed this week
X.ST: This privilege escalation vulnerability has lurked within Windows for 20 years.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A high-level description of the bug in MSCTF.DLL.

X.T: Forum cracks the vintage passwords of Ken Thompson and other Unix pioneers
X.ST: Security in the early days of Unix was poor. Then, there were the passwords.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Breaking the passwords from a 1980 BSD snapshot.

X.T: DNS Cache Poisoning - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A high-level description of DNS poisoning.

X.T: The First Internet Worm (Morris Worm) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another telling of the Robert Morris Internet Worm, but this one does not go in the details.

X.T: The Internet’s Most Notorious Botnet Has an Alarming New Trick
X.ST: The hackers behind TrickBot have begun probing victim PCs for vulnerable firmware, which would let them persist on devices undetected.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The bot is checking if the UEFI is vulnerable.

X.T: OpenSSL fixes high-severity flaw that allows hackers to crash servers
X.ST: The widely used code library is also purged of a certificate verification bypass.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Two bugs are fixed: a null pointer dereference and some conditions allowing to bypass the certificate verification.

X.T: 5 ways to prevent code injection in JavaScript and Node.js

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some basic information about code injection in JavaScript and an advertisement for Snyk.

X.T: Affaire Pegasus : comment des téléphones ont-ils pu être contaminés sans action de leur propriétaire ?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information about how Pegasus works.

X.T: SolarWinds and the Holiday Bear Campaign: A Case Study for the Classroom

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An overview of how Russia’s SVR performed the SolarWinds attack.

X.T: Hacking et virus informatiques (dans le monde réel) bonus: Corewar! - Passe-science #43

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An introduction to buffer overflows and viruses.

X.T: The Invisible JavaScript Backdoor

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using invisible characters or homoglyphs to hide code instructions in JavaScript code.

X.T: How $323M in crypto was stolen from a blockchain bridge called Wormhole
X.ST: Cryptocurrency carries risk. Blockchain bridges heighten it.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Attackers can force Amazon Echos to hack themselves with self-issued commands
X.ST: Popular “smart” device follows commands issued by its own speaker. What could go wrong?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Linux has been bitten by its most high-severity vulnerability in years
X.ST: Dirty Pipe has the potential to smudge people using Linux and Linux derivitives.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of Dirty Pipe, an uninitialised variable allows an attacker to overwrite a file cached in memory.

X.T: First Microsoft, then Okta: New ransomware gang posts data from both
X.ST: If you haven't heard of Lapsus$, you have now. It probably won't be the last time.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Lapsus$, a new hacker group, claims to have hacked into Okta and Microsoft.

X.T: A Mysterious Satellite Hack Has Victims Far Beyond Ukraine
X.ST: The biggest hack since Russia’s war began knocked thousands of people offline. The spillover extends deep into Europe.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An attack destroyed thousands of Viasat satellite modems.

X.T: Mystery solved in destructive attack that knocked out >10k Viasat modems
X.ST: AcidRain is the seventh wiper associated with the Russian invasion of Ukraine.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: SentinelOne analysed the modem wiper.

X.T: North Korean hackers unleashed Chrome 0-day exploit on hundreds of US targets
X.ST: Critical vulnerability exploited by 2 groups both working for the North Korean government.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The description of a complex attack using social engineering to trick receivers to visit legitimate sites containing a malicious iframe.

X.T: Russia's Sandworm Hackers Attempted a Third Blackout in Ukraine
X.ST: The attack was the first in five years to use Sandworm's Industroyer malware, which is designed to automatically trigger power disruptions.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Hackers can infect >100 Lenovo models with unremovable malware. Are you patched?
X.ST: Exploiting critical UEFI vulnerabilities could allow malware to hide in firmware.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Backdoor in public repository used new form of attack to target big firms
X.ST: Dependency confusion attacks exploit our trust in public code repositories.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of dependency confusion.

X.T: “PACMAN” Hack Breaks Apple M1’s Last Line of Defense
X.ST: How many dominos could fall if this centerpiece CPU’s weakness pans out?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A side channel attack has been found to bypass Apple’s Pointer Authentication Code.

X.T: Hardcoded password in Confluence app has been leaked on Twitter
X.ST: Advisory had already warned hardcoded password was "trivial to obtain."

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Atlassian is quite bad at security.

X.T: Critical hole in Atlassian Bitbucket allows any miscreant to hijack servers
X.ST: Grab and deploy this backend update if you offer even repo read access

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Atlassian continues to have big security issues.

X.T: Une "arnaque à l'avis de passage" profite d'une faille informatique de La Poste
X.ST: La ville de Montpellier semble touchée par une campagne d'escroqueries. Des habitants ont reçu de faux avis de passage de La Poste redirigeant vers un site demandant leurs coordonnées bancaires.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Phishing using a fake paper notice and a bug of La Poste.

X.T: Numerous orgs hacked after installing weaponized open source apps
X.ST: PuTTY, KiTTY, TightVNC, Sumatra PDF Reader, and muPDF/Subliminal Recording all targeted.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: North Korean hackers are using social engineering and Trojanized software.

X.T: Mystery hackers are “hyperjacking” targets for insidious spying
X.ST: After decades of warnings, group figured out how to hijack virtualization software.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: USENIX Security '22 - Lend Me Your Ear: Passive Remote Physical Side Channels on PCs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Extracting data by using the fact that the CPU interferes with the audio when using Voice-over-IP applications.

X.T: First LastPass, now Slack and CircleCI. The hacks go on (and will likely worsen)
X.ST: Don't expect victims to be forthcoming. Their alerts conceal more than they reveal.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: What Twitter’s 200 Million-User Email Leak Actually Means
X.ST: The exposure of hundreds of millions of email addresses puts pseudonymous users of the social network at risk.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The impact of the email scrapping of 2021.

X.T: More malicious packages posted to online repository. This time it’s PyPI
X.ST: It's not always easy to spot malicious impostors posing as legit downloads.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: How This SQL Command Blew Up a Billion Dollar Company

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A hypothetical scenario on how Heartland Payment Systems has been hacked in 2007.

X.T: Acropalypse Now - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It was possible to recover pixels cropped out of an Android screenshot.

X.T: Capital One's $200M Cloud Data Breach

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Capital One’s data breach in AWS by a former AWS software engineer.

X.T: Those scary warnings of juice jacking in airports and hotels? They’re mostly nonsense
X.ST: Juice jacking attacks on mobile phones are nonexistent. So why are we so afraid?

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of possible attacks using a USB connection, but they are too complex to be wildly used in a public charging station.

X.T: LogJam Attack - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the LogJam vulnerability.

X.T: Power LED Attack - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A side channel attack using the fact that the LED light level is impacted when the CPU computes more data.

X.T: Closing vulnerabilities in Decidim, a Ruby-based citizen participation platform
X.ST: This blog post describes two security vulnerabilities in Decidim, a digital platform for citizen participation. Both vulnerabilities were addressed by the Decidim team with corresponding update releases for the supported versions in May 2023.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of two vulnerabilities: a XSS and a data exfiltration.

X.T: Hackers Could Have Scored Unlimited Airline Miles by Targeting One Platform
X.ST: Flaws in the Points.com platform, which is used to manage dozens of major travel rewards programs, exposed user data—and could have let an attacker snag some extra perks.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: How Not To Secure Your Company (Target Data Breach)

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Target Data Breach, from compromising a third-party vendor up to infecting Target’s POS systems.

X.T: TETRA Vulnerability (TETRA:BURST) - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: TETRA, a proprietary encryption mechanism for police radio communication, is broken.

X.T: Microsoft menace la sécurité nationale

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some little information about Microsoft hack and, as usual with LêNguyên Hoang, a long discourse about the importance of cybersecurity.

X.T: GPUs from all major suppliers are vulnerable to new pixel-stealing attack
X.ST: A previously unknown compression side channel in GPUs can expose images thought to be private.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic presentation of GPU.zip, a GPU side channel attack.

X.T: Intel fixes high-severity CPU bug that causes “very strange behavior”
X.ST: Among other things, bug allows code running inside a VM to crash hypervisors.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The subtitle says it all.

X.T: Researchers figure out how to bypass the fingerprint readers in most Windows PCs
X.ST: Microsoft's Surface didn't even use the Microsoft-developed security protocol.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Security researchers were able, using different ways, to bypass fingerprint sensor on several laptops.

X.T: Securing our home labs: Frigate code review
X.ST: This blog post describes two linked vulnerabilities found in Frigate, an AI-powered security camera manager, that could have enabled an attacker to silently gain remote code execution.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Hacking a poorly secured Python application.

X.T: Playing with Fire – How We Executed a Critical Supply Chain Attack on PyTorch

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using self-hosted runners to get access to some secrets.

X.T: A Flaw in Millions of Apple, AMD, and Qualcomm GPUs Could Expose AI Data
X.ST: Patching every device affected by the LeftoverLocals vulnerability—which includes some iPhones, iPads, and Macs—may prove difficult.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: LeftoverLocals: a vulnerability that allows data recovery from GPU memory created by another process.

X.T: MAJOR EXPLOIT: GitLab was Hacked with an IMAGE??

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Exploiting a wrong regex in a Perl script.

X.T: How I got scammed

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How you can get phished even when you know about security.

X.T: Hackers can read private AI-assistant chats even though they’re encrypted
X.ST: All non-Google chat GPTs affected by side channel that leaks responses sent to users.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using token lengths to rebuild the chatbot anwers.

X.T: Hackers Found a Way to Open Any of 3 Million Hotel Keycard Locks in Seconds
X.ST: The company behind the Saflok-brand door locks is offering a fix, but it may take months or years to reach some hotels.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A team of hackers is able to reconfigure and open Dormakaba’s locks.

X.T: Back to the Hype: An Update on How Cybercriminals Are Using GenAI
X.ST: Generative AI continues to be misused and abused by malicious individuals. In this article, we dive into new criminal LLMs, criminal services with ChatGPT-like capabilities, and deepfakes being offered on criminal sites.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: It seems that criminals are not yet utilising the capabilities of AI. But some are bullshitting other ones, as in other economic domains.

X.T: GhostStripe attack haunts self-driving cars by making them ignore road signs
X.ST: Cameras tested are specced for Baidu's Apollo

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another attack on self-driving cars.

X.T: Polyfill supply chain attack hits 100K+ sites

ARTICLE.COMMENT: cdn.polyfill.io injects malware in sites using it to get polyfill.js.

X.T: SQL Injection Attacks by Example

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic, detailed, and slow description of a SQL injection attack.

X.T: Bobby Tables

ARTICLE.COMMENT: SQL is too dangerous, it should not be used anymore.

X.T: Smashing The Stack For Fun And Profit
Smashing The Stack For Fun And Profit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very well-known article: EliasLevyAleph One describes what is a buffer overflow exploit and how to exploit it.

X.T: Ping of Death

ARTICLE.COMMENT: At the beginning of Internet explosion, there were some major security issues: you could simply crash a machine by sending an illegal IP packet…

X.T: TAKING ADVANTAGE OF NON-TERMINATED ADJACENT MEMORY SPACES

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A small variation of the buffer overflow by using contiguous buffers.

X.T: Bypassing StackGuard and StackShield

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some new overflow techniques: overwriting the return address despite the presence of a canary, patching the atexit table and patching the global offset table.

X.T: Smashing C++ VPTRs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another buffer overflow technique: overwriting the VPTR table.

X.T: SHARED LIBRARY CALL REDIRECTION VIA ELF PLT INFECTION

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Silvio describes how to hijack the procedure linkage table (this is done by patching the executable).

X.T: Remotely Exploitable Buffer Overflow in Outlook "Malformed E-mail MIME Header" Vulnerability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A nice buffer overflow in Outlook: no need to open an attachment or even to read the mail, you could be infected by a virus… An exploit is provided.

X.T: JPEG COM Marker Processing Vulnerability in Netscape Browsers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A nice way to make Netscape execute code recorded in a JPEG file!

X.T: Netscape SmartDownload Overflow

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A buffer overflow in SmartDownload, no exploit provided.

X.T: Once upon a free()...

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of System V and GNU C malloc implementations with some way to generate and exploit overflow in the heap.

X.T: Vudo - An object superstitiously believed to embody magical powers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An impressive description of the sudo exploit (which uses a corruption of the heap) with a detailed analysis of Doug Lea malloc library.

X.T: The advanced return-into-lib(c) exploits: PaX case study

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to circumvent OSes with a non executable stack by calling functions in the loaded shared libraries.

X.T: No SIGSEGV anymore

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An idea still to be exploited, preloading a SIGSEGV event handler to redirect the program execution.

X.T: Writing UTF-8 compatible shellcodes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of the conditions necessary to create a shellcode which is a valid UTF8 string and some tricks to fulfil them.

X.T: More info on format bugs.
Format string vulnerability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: How to exploit format string bugs to examine the stack and execute a root shell.

X.T: Write It Secure: Format Strings and Locale Filtering

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A non-technical overview of format string exploit and locale hijacks.

X.T: Basic Integer Overflow

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic, yet effective, introduction to integer overflow/wrap around exploits.

X.T: Smashing The Kernel Stack For Fun And Profit

ARTICLE.COMMENT: An exploit for the select() OpenBSD signed/unsigned vulnerability.

X.T: Cross Site Scripting Info: Encoding Examples

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Same thing from the Apache group.

X.T: Understanding Malicious Content Mitigation for Web Developers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice to avoid cross-site scripting. But the problem is so complex that this is just an overview.

X.T: CERT® Advisory CA-2000-02 Malicious HTML Tags Embedded in Client Web Requests

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This CERT Advisory is a basic presentation of the cross-site scripting vulnerability.

X.T: Cross-site scripting
X.ST: Use a custom tag library to encode dynamic content

ARTICLE.COMMENT: After a quick presentation of some types of cross-site scripting attacks, the author describes how to easily avoid them in JSP by using a private tag.

X.T: Prevent cross-site request forgery: Know the hidden danger in your browser tabs
X.ST: Learn to prevent cross-site request forgery or your clients might do a hacker's bidding without knowing it

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The title says it all.

X.T: Secure programmer: Prevent race conditions
X.ST: Resource contention can be used against you

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some advice on avoiding race condition attacks when using files.

X.T: Delivering Signals for Fun and Profit
X.ST: Understanding, exploiting and preventing signal-handling related vulnerabilities.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Signal handlers are difficult to write correctly, so many of them can be exploited as security holes.

X.T: A Real Remedy for Phishers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Bruce opinion is that a company should be considered responsible when one of its customer is victim of phishing.

X.T: Two Things That Bother Me About Google's New Firefox Extension

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The Google’s Firefox extension to flag phishing use unencrypted HTTP request, this may be a problem.

X.T: Identifying Suspicious URLs: An Application of Large-Scale Online Learning

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A study of several algorithms to automatically classify phishing vs. benign URLs.

X.T: Devious New Phishing Tactic Targets Tabs

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A description of a new kind of phishing attack: the tabnabbing, where a hidden type morphs into a phishing page to trap the inattentive user.

X.T: Microsoft Word Documents that "Phone Home"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A clever way to use Web bugs: embed them in an Office document!

X.T: Email Wiretapping

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Even more clever, use the Web bugs to trace the forward and added text to an email you have sent.

X.T: Denial of Service via Algorithmic Complexity Attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A DoS based on finding the worst case of use of a hash table, the authors propose their own version of a universal hashing to fix the issue.

X.T: Protect your Apache server from DoS attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some information on Apache and DoS attacks, but this article is not very clear and informative.

X.T: About that hash flooding vulnerability in Node.js…

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another DoD attack by flooding a hash table. The V8 team had trouble to get a proper fix.

X.T: Hash Collisions (The Poisoned Message Attack)
X.ST: "The Story of Alice and her Boss"

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The authors have created two PostScript files with the same MD5 checksum.

X.T: Enough With The Rainbow Tables: What You Need To Know About Secure Password Schemes

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Encoding passwords with as a simple MD5 checksum is a bad idea, Thomas suggests some better methods.

X.T: Google as a password cracker

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Google to break a MD5 checksum.

X.T: Predicting the winner of the 2008 US Presidential Elections using a Sony PlayStation 3

ARTICLE.COMMENT: "3D5 15 DEAD": the authors have created 12 meaningful PDF files with the same MD5 checksum.

X.T: Cryptanalysis of SHA-1

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A Chinese team has been able to divide the search space by 211. SHA-1’s future starts to look like MD5’s future.

X.T: Ajax Security Dangers

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Yet another white paper on AJAX security. The only interest here is that it describes possible issues with AJAX bridging.

X.T: Ajax Security Basics

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Some generalities about AJAX security and the difficulty to test it.

X.T: Top 10 Ajax Security Holes and Driving Factors

ARTICLE.COMMENT: This is not a list of possible attacks, just random thoughts about where a malicious script could be injected.

X.T: Mashup security
X.ST: Technologies and techniques for securing UI artifacts and data in a mashup

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A list of security issues when building mashups, but the description is too terse to be really useful.

X.T: Clickjacking

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A presentation of the attack and possible ways to exploit it.

X.T: This Week in HTML 5 – Episode 7

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The WHATWG and W3C HTML Working Group is starting to look at solutions to avoid clickjacking.

X.T: Clickjacking: Web pages can see and hear you

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A demonstration of clickjacking to get access to the camera and snoop the victim.

X.T: Java Deployment Toolkit Performs Insufficient Validation of Parameters

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Java Deployment Toolkit plugin allows launching javaws without any checks.

X.T: Google Your Site For Security Vulnerabilities

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Using Google to find security holes on Web servers.

X.T: Bulletproof your organization against Google hacking: Assess your vulnerability to these ten simple security searches

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A longer description of the same techniques.

X.T: L'attaque SPECTRE

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A very basic, but clear, description of the problem.

X.T: L'attaque MELTDOWN

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The same for Meltdown. The author should have merged the two articles since they contain mostly the same words!

X.T: Spectre & Meltdown - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple explanation of the Spectre attack.

X.T: Why Raspberry Pi isn’t vulnerable to Spectre or Meltdown

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic and clear explanation of CPU optimisations and how Meltdown and Spectre exploit them.

X.T: Meltdown Redux: Intel Flaw Lets Hackers Siphon Secrets from Millions of PCs
X.ST: Two different groups of researchers found another speculative execution attack that can steal all the data a CPU touches.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Other security attacks related to the speculative execution have been found in Intel’s CPUs.

X.T: Zip Slip Vulnerability

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A simple exploit of the fact that the code does not check that files extracted for a Zip file are not in written in another directory.

X.T: What's Behind Port Smash? - Computerphile

ARTICLE.COMMENT: A basic description of hyperthreading and how Port Smash works.

X.T: A timing attack with CSS selectors and Javascript

ARTICLE.COMMENT: Timing CSS evaluation time of a page using jQuery(location.hash) to extract some information from the page.

X.T: Abusing jQuery for CSS powered timing attacks

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The details of using the attack on redhat.com.

X.T: Patch fixing critical Log4J 0-day has its own vulnerability that’s under exploit
X.ST: If you've patched using Log4J 2.15.0, it's time to consider updating again. Stat.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The first fix of log4j was not complete…

X.T: Log4j : une autre vulnérabilité corrigée par Apache
X.ST: Plus d'une semaine après la publication de la mise à jour 2.17 de la bibliothèque de journalisation Log4j d'Apache Logging, une faille CVE-2021-44832 l'affectant est comblée. La montée de version vers la 2.17.1 est à effectuer dès que possible.

ARTICLE.COMMENT: The saga continues…
